titleInfo.title: Correspondence from J. S. Burrow to F. T. Burrow, February 16, 1862

mods.abstract: J. S. Burrow writes his brother from Chester County detailing his financial problems, his inability to collect money until cotton comes to market, his desire to move from Jacks Creek for better money-making opportunities, and his fear that he will eventually have to enter military service. He contends General Pillow will re-take Ft. Henry if he can muster enough troops. He notes that unconfirmed rumors state Pillow has whipped the enemy at Fort Donelson.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
mods.abstract: [Page 1] “Jacks Creek February 16th 1862 Der Brother I received your Letter I was very glad to her that you was all well it found all of you sad that you had jest got home from a visit at the fort I was prod to her that Nick was well I wold be glad to se him & the balanc of you but times is so hard & mony scars I can not tell when I can com you Sad Sumphen a bout me a comin thar to work I recon that I cold make more thar then I can her but I havent got money to pay my way thar but if I had money I wold move thar as sone as I cold git thar but I can not colect Eny money at this time unless Coton cam in markett I cold git to wark for the goverment her if I cold leave my famley but I cant git no pursen to stay with them I wish I cold git a way from her for I am gitin tierd of the plase I can make a livin her and that is all I cant make Eny money over that theer is a good deale of Exsitement her sence the linkens its have took forte henry but I think that ginerl Piller will retake it a gin if he can git farse a nuff the nuse is that he has whipe them at forte donelsin but I dont no that it is the case the Boys is all gon from her this place is vary lomson now som of them is in the Cavlery & som in inferny thar is fore or five men left her McCarkle & houston Tablen chris her” [Page 2] “& my self but I donte know how longe we will git to stay if the war continus I Exspect we will all have to go this is a distresin times on us but we will have to fite or Run & I donte think the Tenessee Boys will Run much Chris did git a letter from Brouther Wiley ses he is comin back her as son as he can I am vary lomson her know sence the boys is gon but thar ar stain at Henderson depo 9 miles from her you must excuse my letter paper for I cant git Eny other sorte onley Book paper Right when you can & I will do the same so I will close with these few lines I Remain your Lovin Brother un tell deth I S Burro To F T Burro & famley”

titleInfo.title: Civilian Life in the Civil War

relatedItem.abstract: The items in this collection offer new perspectives into the lives of numerous non-combatants during the Civil War in Tennessee and throughout the southeast. The correspondence and primary writings touch on several themes relating to the home front, including the diverse roles of women, the relationship between occupying/invading forces and civilians, personal beliefs regarding secession and the war, and the effect of the war on African American Tennesseans. These sources can offer the public a lens into the lives of many Civil War non-combatant men and women, a subject of increasing importance in Civil War scholarship...
